Subsubseries I: Select Subcommittee on Education

Brademas served as chairman of this subcommittee from 1969 to 1979. There is 5 linear feet of material dating from 1968 to 1980. Materials include constituent correspondence, interoffice memoranda, subcommittee memoranda, hearing testimony, transcripts, opening statements and summaries, committee prints, committee reports, conference materials, floor statements, clippings, background reports and other materials on specific legislation considered by the subcommittee.

This subseries documents Brademas' efforts to create child development legislation. In 1969, he began drafting legislation and in cooperation with Senator Walter Mondale (D-Minn.) conducted hearings over the next three years. See "Comprehensive Child Development Act" folders for materials regarding the initial Comprehensive Child Development Act, including copies of the bill, comparisons with other bills, and analysis of the bill. "Child and Family Services: Clippings" contains additional material on the bill, including general background articles and numerous articles about the legislation authored by Brademas. Brademas and Mondale's subsequent attempts to pass child development legislation are documented in the "Child & Family Services" folders. Attacks on this bill by the media are well documented in the files, including a flyer that sparked controversy over the bill (see "Child & Family Services: Print" for a copy of the flyer and "Child & Family Services: Rebuttal" for Brademas' point-by-point rebuttal).

The National Institute of Education (NIE) folders document the reauthorization of appropriations for the NIE during the 94th and 96th Congress. Also present are materials related to the oversight of the Institute, including the monitoring of specific departments -- see Compensatory Education, Dissemination & Resources Group, Educational Laboratories and Centers, National Council on Educational Research, and Review.

Brademas' efforts on behalf of vocational rehabilitation and the rights of handicapped individuals can be found in folders on the Handicapped, Revenue Sharing, and Vocational Rehabilitation. The Handicapped folders document the creation of the Education for All Handicapped Act of 1975 and contain some constituent correspondence discussing the implications of its implementation. Brademas' request for the General Accounting Office (GAO) to determine the extent to which revenue sharing funds were being targeted to handicapped of all ages and handicapped children is included in the Revenue Sharing folders.

Materials related to the creation of the Department of Education and the implications of its jurisdiction over certain educational programs can be found in the Department of Education folders as well as Vocational Rehabilitation folders. Materials detail amendments and other proposals to waive the requirement of a single organizational unit in the Rehabilitation Act of 1973. The Comprehensive Rehabilitation Services Amendments of 1978 are documented in Box I:07, Folders 24-27 and Box I:08, Folders 2-5, 15-32.

Additional files provide general overview information (see folders on Legislation: 96th Congress) or administrative information (see folders on the Budget; Correspondence Files for 1978 (contain outgoing correspondence filed alphabetically by recipient); and Educational Policy Fellows Program. "
